author: Special Correspondent
text:
Sansar Chand, Central Excise Commissioner, held a meeting with the jewellers association here on Wednesday in the wake of apprehension expressed by them on the one per cent excise duty imposed on jewellery by the Central government.

The meeting was organised to drive home the important aspects of the levy and clarify doubts of participants. The Commissioner informed them that the Centre had decided to constitute a sub-committee to interact with trade and industry on tax laws. He said the associations would be given an opportunity to represent before the committee and submit a representation.

The committee would submit its report within 60 days of its constitution.

A circular had been issued by the board specifying the procedures to be followed till the committee’s recommendations were finalised. As per the procedures, no Central Excise officer would visit the manufacturing units/ shops / place of business / residence of the jewellers. The other procedures to be followed include no search or seizure of stocks by any central excise official, all payments of central excise duty would be based on first sale invoice value and no arrest or criminal prosecution of any jeweller would be done.

The participants stated that they would give in writing their doubts on certain aspects in due course. Assuring full cooperation to the jewellers, the Commissioner said their representations would be forwarded to the Central Board of Excise and Customs through the Chief Commissioner of Central Excise and Service Tax, Coimbatore.

Similar meetings with jewellers were conducted at Thanjavur, Karaikal and Karur, a press release from the office of the Commissioner of Central Excise and Service Tax here said.
title: Excise Commissioner holds meeting with jewellers
